# 5E Lesson Plan: Light and Motion on the Rails

---

## Core Science Concepts from Image Analysis

- **Light and Shadows:** The photograph shows a light-rail train with areas of darkness (windows and shadowed sections) and areas where light reflects off the metal and paint surfaces—illustrating how objects can be visible when illuminated and harder to see in darkness.
- **Movement and Energy:** The train demonstrates motion and the concept that moving objects have energy; the overhead electrical lines and pantograph (the arm on top connecting to power) show how energy is transferred to make the train move.
- **Materials and Properties:** The train is made of different materials (metal, glass, paint) that interact with light differently—some materials are shiny (reflect light), while others are dark (absorb light).
- **Electrical Energy:** The overhead wires and pantograph system visibly show how electricity powers the train, connecting to the concept that energy makes things move.

---

## Lesson Title

**Lights, Rails, and Moving Trains: Exploring Light and Motion**

---

## Lesson Overview

- **Grade Level:** First Grade
- **Subject:** Science (Physical Science)
- **Time Allotment:** Two 45-minute sessions (or 90 minutes total, flexible across two days)
- **NGSS Standards:** 
  - 1-PS4-2 (Make observations to construct an evidence-based account that objects in darkness can be seen only when illuminated)
  - 1-PS4-3 (Plan and conduct investigations to determine the effect of placing objects made with different materials in the path of a beam of light)

---

## Learning Objectives

Students will be able to:
- Observe and explain that objects are easier to see when light shines on them.
- Investigate how different materials (shiny, dark, clear) interact with light in different ways.
- Describe that trains and other vehicles need energy (like electricity) to move.
- Use light and shadows to solve a simple communication problem (extension).

---

## 5E Lesson Sequence

---

### 1. ENGAGE (10-15 minutes)

**Objective:** Capture student interest and activate prior knowledge about light, visibility, and motion using the photograph.

**Materials:**
- Printed color photograph of the light-rail train (one copy for teacher display, or digital projection)
- Optional: Picture of the same location at night (for comparison, if available)
- Chart paper and markers
- Classroom lights (for demonstration)

**Activity:**

1. **Display the photograph** on a screen or poster at the front of the room. Ask students to sit in a circle where they can all see clearly.

2. **Ask these specific discussion questions** (pause for 3-5 student responses each):
   - "What do you see in this picture? What is this vehicle called?" *(Allow students to name the train/tram.)*
   - "Why can we see the train so clearly in this picture? What is helping us see it?" *(Guide them to notice the bright sky and light shining on the train.)*
   - "Do you see any parts of the train that look very dark or shadowy? Why do you think those parts look darker?" *(Point to the windows or shadowed areas.)*
   - "How does this train move? What do you think makes it go?" *(Draw attention to the overhead wires and pantograph arm on top.)*

3. **Prediction/Wonder Prompt:**
   - "If it was nighttime and there were no lights, could we see this train? What would happen?" 
   - Invite students to share their ideas. Record 2-3 predictions on chart paper: *"We couldn't see it" / "It would be invisible" / "We would need lights."*

4. **Show a picture of the same location at dusk or night** (if available). Ask: *"See? In the dark, it's hard to see the train. But if lights were on the train or around it, we could see it again!"*

**Transition:** "Today, we're going to do our own experiments with light to see how it helps us see things—just like the light in this picture helps us see the train!"

---

### 2. EXPLORE (20-25 minutes)

**Objective:** Students investigate how light affects visibility and how different materials interact with light.

**Materials** (per pair/small group of 2-3 students):
- One flashlight or small lamp (LED flashlights are safe and work well)
- 3-4 objects to test (one shiny/reflective: aluminum foil or metallic paper; one dark: black construction paper or dark cloth; one clear: plastic wrap or clear plastic sheet; one regular: white paper)
- Small dark box or paper bag (to create a "dark space")
- Index cards for recording
- Pencils/crayons

**Activity:**

**Part A: Seeing in Light vs. Darkness (10 minutes)**

1. **Divide the class into pairs or small groups of 3.** Give each group a flashlight and one small object (start with the shiny object).

2. **First, have groups turn ON the overhead classroom lights.** Ask: *"Can you see your object clearly? What does it look like?"*
   - Students observe and point to the object, describe its color and texture.

3. **Darken the room slightly** (close blinds or dim lights). Ask: *"Is it harder to see the object now? Why?"*
   - Students notice the object becomes less visible.

4. **Have students shine the flashlight directly on the object.** Ask: *"What happened? Can you see it again? What changed?"*
   - Students observe that the light made the object visible again.
   - Draw a simple picture on an index card showing: **darkness = hard to see** and **light = easy to see**.

**Part B: How Different Materials Interact with Light (10-15 minutes)**

1. **Give each group 3-4 different materials** (shiny, dark, clear, regular paper).

2. **In the darkened room, have students shine the flashlight at each material one at a time.** Ask questions as they test:
   - *"Does the light bounce off it or shine through it? What do you see?"*
   - *"Is it bright or dark?"*
   - *"Can you see the light on the material?"*

3. **Students record observations** by:
   - Drawing pictures of what they see (very bright, a little bright, dark, see-through)
   - OR using simple words: "shiny," "dark," "see-through," "bright"

4. **Teacher circulates and asks probing questions:**
   - *"Why do you think this one looks so bright?"* (Hint: the shiny material bounces light back)
   - *"What happens when light hits the dark paper?"* (It doesn't bounce back; it gets absorbed)
   - *"Can light go through the clear material?"* (Yes, so we can see through it)

**Expected Student Outcomes:**
- Students discover that light makes objects visible.
- Students notice that different materials look different when light shines on them (some are bright, some are dark, some are transparent).
- Students record simple observations through drawings or words.

---

### 3. EXPLAIN (15-20 minutes)

**Objective:** Introduce formal vocabulary and connect the exploration back to the train photograph.

**Materials:**
- Chart paper and markers
- Photograph of the train (redisplay)
- Picture cards showing: shiny/metallic objects, dark objects, clear objects (examples: mirror, black cloth, window)
- Vocabulary poster template (pre-made or created live with students)

**Activity:**

1. **Group Share-Out (5 minutes):**
   - Call on 3-4 groups to share one discovery from their light exploration.
   - *"Tell us what happened when you shined the light on the shiny material. What did you see?"*
   - Record key words on chart paper: "bright," "bounced," "reflected," "could see."

2. **Introduce Key Vocabulary (8-10 minutes):**

   Create a simple anchor chart with words and pictures:

   | **Term** | **Student-Friendly Definition** | **Example from Train Photo** |
   |---|---|---|
   | **Light** | Energy that helps us see things. | The sunlight shining on the train in the photo. |
   | **Dark/Darkness** | When there is no light. Things are hard to see. | The shadowy windows and inside of the train. |
   | **Shiny** | A surface that bounces light back. It looks very bright. | The silver-white metal and paint of the train body. |
   | **Reflects** | When light bounces off something and comes back to our eyes. | The light bouncing off the shiny train metal. |
   | **Transparent** | You can see through it. Light goes through it. | The windows on the train—we can see inside! |

3. **Connect Back to the Train Photo (5 minutes):**
   - Display the train photograph again.
   - Point to the shiny metal parts: *"See how bright the train looks? That's because sunlight is reflecting—bouncing off—the shiny metal. That's why we can see it so clearly."*
   - Point to the dark windows: *"These parts are darker because the light isn't bouncing back at us as much. But look—we can see through the clear windows! Light travels right through the transparent glass."*
   - Ask: *"If this train was in the dark with no sun and no lights, would it be as shiny and bright? No—we'd need lights to make it visible, just like you discovered with your flashlights!"*

4. **Check for Understanding:**
   - Ask simple yes/no and recall questions:
     - *"If something is shiny, does light bounce off it?"* (Yes)
     - *"Can we see through dark materials?"* (No, it's hard)
     - *"What helps us see things?"* (Light)
     - *"Look at the train's windows. What kind of material are they? Can we see through them?"* (Clear/transparent—yes!)

**Expected Student Outcomes:**
- Students can name and define basic vocabulary about light (light, dark, shiny, reflects, transparent).
- Students can point to examples of these concepts in the train photograph.
- Students explain that light helps us see and that different materials interact with light differently.

---

### 4. ELABORATE (15-20 minutes)

**Objective:** Students apply their understanding of light and visibility to a real-world scenario.

**Materials:**
- Flashlights (same as Explore, or string of battery-operated LED lights)
- Toy train or toy car (optional, but helpful for visual connection)
- Chart paper or poster board
- Markers, construction paper, aluminum foil
- Tape
- Small boxes or paper bags

**Activity:**

**Scenario: "Making the Train Visible at Night"**

1. **Present the Problem (2 minutes):**
   - *"Imagine it's nighttime, and a train needs to travel, but it's very dark. People can't see the train coming. What could we do to make the train visible so people know it's there and can stay safe?"*
   - Allow 2-3 student ideas.

2. **Design and Build Activity (12-15 minutes):**
   - **Divide students into pairs or small groups.**
   - Give each group materials: construction paper, aluminum foil, a small box (representing a train car), a flashlight.
   - **Challenge:** *"Design a way to make your train car bright and visible at night using light and shiny materials. You can wrap it, decorate it, or add lights."*
   
   **Guided questions as they work:**
   - *"What materials will make your train easier to see?"*
   - *"Should you use shiny materials or dark materials? Why?"*
   - *"Where would lights be most helpful?"*

3. **Test and Share (3-5 minutes):**
   - Dim the classroom lights.
   - Have each group show their train car and explain their choices.
   - *"Why did you choose shiny materials?" "Where did you place the light and why?"*

**Teacher Role:**
- Facilitate without giving answers: *"What did you learn about shiny materials? Would that help make the train visible?"*
- Help students troubleshoot if their design isn't working as expected.
- Ask them to predict what they might change.

**Expected Student Outcomes:**
- Students apply their understanding that light and shiny materials make things visible.
- Students design and build a model demonstrating this principle.
- Students explain their design choices using new vocabulary (shiny, reflects, light, visible).

---

### 5. EVALUATE

**Objective:** Assess student understanding of light, visibility, and how materials interact with light.

**Activity:**

**Formative Assessment (during Explore & Elaborate):**
- Observe students' predictions and questions during Engage.
- Listen to group discussions and reasoning during Explore: *"Why do you think the light bounced off that?"*
- Check drawings/recordings in Explore for evidence of observation.
- Note student language during Explain: Are they using new vocabulary correctly?
- Observe design choices during Elaborate and listen to their explanations.

**Exit Ticket or Summative Assessment (5-7 minutes):**

Choose ONE of these approaches:

**Option A: Oral Exit Ticket (for early First Grade or emergent readers)**
- Show students the train photograph one more time.
- Ask 2-3 of these questions (you choose based on your class):
  1. *"Why can we see the train so clearly in this picture?"* *(Listen for: "It's bright" / "There's light" / "The sun is shining on it")*
  2. *"What parts of the train are hard to see? Why?"* *(Listen for: "The dark parts" / "The windows are dark inside" / recognizing shadowed areas)*
  3. *"If this train was moving at night with no lights, would it be easy to see?"* *(Listen for: "No" and a reason like "It would be too dark" / "We'd need lights")*
  4. *"If I gave you a shiny mirror and a dark sock, which one would bounce light back to us?"* *(Listen for: "The shiny mirror")*

**Option B: Picture-Sorting Exit Ticket (for visual learners)**
- Show 4-5 simple picture cards:
  - A shiny object (mirror, metal)
  - A dark object (black cloth, shadow)
  - A clear object (window, plastic wrap)
  - An object in darkness
  - An object in bright light
- Ask: *"Which of these would be easy to see? Which would be hard to see? Point and tell me why."*

**Option C: Written/Drawing Exit Ticket (for older First Grade or writing-ready students)**
- Give each student a simple worksheet with 2-3 prompts:
  - Draw a picture of something you saw in our light experiments.
  - Write or dictate: "Light helps us see because _______."
  - Circle: If something is shiny, does light bounce off it? **YES / NO**

**Success Criteria for Student Understanding:**
- Students can explain that **light makes objects visible** (using words or simple sentences).
- Students can identify **shiny vs. dark materials** and explain what happens when light shines on each.
- Students can apply this understanding to a **real-world context** (like making a train visible at night).
- Students use **new vocabulary** appropriately (light, dark, shiny, reflects, transparent).

**Expected Student Outcomes:**
- 80% of students can correctly answer 2 out of 3 exit ticket questions, demonstrating understanding of how light affects visibility.
- Students can point to examples in the train photo and explain them using new vocabulary.
- Student-designed "visible trains" from Elaborate show thoughtful use of light and shiny materials.

---

## Differentiation

### Support (Scaffolding for Struggling Learners)

1. **Simplified Vocabulary:**
   - Use only 2-3 vocabulary words instead of all 5 (focus on: light, dark, shiny).
   - Repeat definitions multiple times with visual examples.
   - Create a personal vocabulary card with pictures the student can reference.

2. **Hands-On Manipulation:**
   - Pair students with a strong peer during Explore; give them fewer materials to test (2 instead of 4).
   - Allow extended time with flashlight activities; let students repeat tests.
   - Use larger, more obviously different materials (shiny aluminum foil vs. black construction paper—maximize contrast).

3. **Simplified Exit Assessment:**
   - Use only Yes/No questions instead of open-ended responses.
   - Point to the photograph: *"Can we see this train? Why?"* (Simpler than asking them to explain cause-and-effect.)
   - Offer multiple-choice answers: *"Is this material shiny or dark?"* with two options and pictures.

4. **One-On-One Check-Ins:**
   - During Explain, pull aside students who seem confused and show them the train photo again.
   - Ask simpler questions: *"Is the train bright or dark in this picture?"*
   - Re-do a mini light experiment at a table with just that student and flashlight.

---

### Challenge (Extensions for Advanced Learners)

1. **Deeper Exploration of Transparency:**
   - During Explore, introduce more materials: colored cellophane, frosted plastic, semi-transparent paper.
   - Ask: *"What happens when you shine light through different colored see-through materials? How do they change the light?"*
   - Have them predict which colors will be brightest when light shines through.

2. **Energy and Motion Connection:**
   - Extend the lesson to address the overhead electrical lines on the train.
   - *"What are those wires on top? They bring electricity to the train to make it move. Electricity is a kind of energy, like light energy. Both help us and power our world."*
   - Create a poster: *"Light gives us the ability to see. Electricity gives the train the ability to move."*
   - Challenge: *"Can you think of other things that use electricity to move or light up?"*

3. **Engineering Design Challenge:**
   - Instead of just adding light to a toy train, challenge them to design a **reflective safety vest or badge** using shiny and dark materials.
   - Criteria: *"Make something that's very visible at night. Use shiny materials because they reflect light."*
   - Test their design with a flashlight and compare brightness to the non-reflective version.

4. **Questioning and Hypothesis:**
   - Instead of telling students what happens when light hits materials, ask them to make **predictions first**.
   - *"What do you think will happen if I shine light on this shiny foil?"*
   - Then test and discuss: *"Were you right? What surprised you?"*
   - This practices scientific thinking and metacognition.

---

## Extension Activities

1. **"Light Hunt" Classroom Scavenger Hunt (10-15 minutes)**
   - Give students a checklist with pictures:
     - Find something **shiny** (reflects light)
     - Find something **dark**
     - Find something **transparent** (see-through)
     - Find something that **gives off light** (lamp, window to sunlight, etc.)
   - Students walk around classroom and check off what they find, drawing pictures.
   - Debrief: *"What did you find that was shiny? What made it shiny?"*
   - **Connection:** This reinforces vocabulary in the real classroom environment.

2. **Shadow Exploration (Follow-up lesson, 20-30 minutes)**
   - Show students how to make shadows with a flashlight and their hands.
   - *"Shadows happen when something blocks light. You can't see a shadow without light!"*
   - Have students create shadow puppet show (hand shapes, holding objects).
   - Activity: Predict shadows before they're made. *"If I hold up this ball, will it make a shadow?"*
   - **Connection:** Deepens understanding of light and darkness; naturally leads to 1-PS4-2.

3. **Comparison: Day and Night Transportation Safety (Homework or Class Discussion, 15 minutes)**
   - Send home or discuss: *"When do we see lights on cars and trains? Why?"*
   - Have families look for lights on vehicles at night (car headlights, brake lights, train lights, bike reflectors).
   - Students draw or bring pictures to class; create a class poster: **"Why Do Vehicles Have Lights?"**
   - **Connection:** Real-world application; reinforces that light helps us see at night; engages families.

---

## Teacher Notes & Tips

- **Safety:** Make sure flashlights are appropriate for First Graders (no sharp edges, not too hot). LED flashlights are ideal.
- **Pacing:** Adjust timing based on your class. Some groups may need more exploration time; others will finish quickly. Have backup flashlights or materials ready.
- **Vocabulary Overload:** Don't force all 5 vocabulary words on every student. "Light," "dark," and "shiny" are the three most critical. "Reflects" and "transparent" can be introduced but don't make them mandatory for all.
- **Photograph Revisiting:** The train photo is your anchor. Keep it visible throughout the lesson and return to it often. Students will make better connections if they see the same example multiple times.
- **Overhead Wires:** If students ask about the wires, you can briefly mention "electricity makes the train move," but keep it simple. Full 1-PS3 standards (energy) are not required for this lesson. Focus on observable light.
- **Room Preparation:** Pre-test all flashlights before the lesson. Ensure you can darken the room enough for students to see the light effects, but not so much that students feel uncomfortable.

---

## Alignment Summary

| **5E Phase** | **NGSS Connection** | **What Students Do** |
|---|---|---|
| **Engage** | Activate prior knowledge | Observe and predict about the train photo; wonder about visibility in darkness |
| **Explore** | **1-PS4-2 & 1-PS4-3** | Investigate light and darkness; test how different materials interact with light |
| **Explain** | **1-PS4-2 & 1-PS4-3** | Learn vocabulary; observe evidence that light affects visibility and material properties affect reflectivity |
| **Elaborate** | **1-PS4-3** | Apply understanding to design a visible train using light and reflective materials |
| **Evaluate** | **1-PS4-2 & 1-PS4-3** | Demonstrate understanding through oral responses, observations, and design choices |

---

This lesson directly uses the photograph to ground abstract concepts in a concrete, visible example that First Graders can understand and explore hands-on. The train's shiny surfaces, dark windows, and reliance on light (both from the sun in the photo and from electrical power via overhead wires) make it an ideal vehicle for teaching light, visibility, and material properties. Well done choosing this image!
